column1: A domain name is an identification string that defines a realm of administrative autonomy
column2: authority or control within the Internet. Domain names are formed by the rules and procedures of the Domain Name System (DNS). Any name registered in the DNS is a domain name. Domain names are used in various networking contexts and application-specific naming and addressing purposes. In general
column3: a domain name represents an Internet Protocol (IP) resource
column4: such as a personal computer used to access the Internet
column5: a server computer hosting a web site
column6: or the web site itself or any other service communicated via the Internet. In 2015
column7: 294 million domain names had been registered.Domain names are organized in subordinate levels (subdomains) of the DNS root domain
column8: which is nameless. The first-level set of domain names are the top-level domains (TLDs)
column10: such as the prominent domains com
column15: and the country code top-level domains (ccTLDs).
